text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The candidate answer explicitly addresses the core limitation derived from Section 44(5) of the Arbitration Act 1996, stating: 'The court shall act only if or to the extent that the arbitral tribunal has no power or is unable for the time being to act effectively.' It further elaborates on this by contrasting the tribunal's power with the court's intervention, noting that the court steps in where the tribunal 'cannot act effectively.'
